thread.title: Paladin cuts costs in break-even bid
thread.title_full: Paladin cuts costs in break-even bid

author: news.com.au
title: Paladin cuts costs in break-even bid
text:
URANIUM miner Paladin plans to continue slashing costs in its bid to break even as uranium prices remain weak.
THE Africa-focused miner says reductions in capital expenditure, corporate costs and debt servicing will cut Paladin's total cash costs by more than $US33 million in full year 2016 compared to the previous year.
The company is carrying out a review over the next three months which is aimed at lowering all-in cash costs to achieve a "cash flow neutral" position. "Further measures that will be implemented are expected to bring the company's overall cash flow to a break-even level that is sustainable even if the current low uranium price environment continues," Paladin said in a statement. In the face of low uranium prices, the company said notching up US$33 million in savings was a key step for Paladin to achieve sustainability". The Perth-based miner said chief executive John Borshoff would accept a 20 per cent pay cut to his $1.4 million salary and other management and directors will have their pay cut following recent earnings losses. Paladin will cut corporate and exploration costs by $US16 million and defer $US10 million in capital expenditure at its biggest mine, Langer Heinrich. Paladin shares were one cent, or 4.4 per cent, lower at 12.5 cents at 1515 AEST.
